title: Brendan Cole apologises for snarky X Factor: Celebrity comment
text:
Brendan learnt his lesson (Picture: WireImage)

Brendan Cole has apologised to his X Factor Celebrity co-stars Max and Harvey for a ‘bitchy’ comment made during the show’s opening episode.

The former Strictly Come Dancing pro, who won the show’s first ever series with news anchor Natasha Kaplinsky, is competing on the talent show spin off with Hollyoaks star Jeremy Edwards, with the pair making up Edwards & Cole.

However, viewers of the series premiere were less than impressed by a dig made by Brendan at 16-year-old TV presenters Max and Harvey.

Commenting on the boys’ claims of social media notoriety, Brendan confided in his singing partner Jeremy: ‘They say they’ve got eight million across social media, but the reality is they’ve only got a chunk on each and it’s all the same.’

Not the best start, eh Brendan.

Fortunately Max and Harvey seemed to see the funny side, tweeting the dancer: ‘Hey @jqedwards @brendancole – there’s this app called Tik Tok where we have a lot of awesome fans!!! Maybe we can make a post on there together sometime?’

Advertisement

Advertisement

However, Brendan seemed mortified at their response and his words, offering up what seems to be a pretty genuine apology for his behaviour.

‘I don’t know what you just said but ok,’ Brendan joked back.

Teen favourites Max and Harvey (Picture: Chelsea Lauren/REX)

‘It did sound very bitchy (shame on me) but make no mistake… you smashed your songs, ours one song was pants and your talent speaks for itself.

‘I’m off with my tail between my legs and you are amazing! Soz boys! You are amazing.’

Someone actually apologising and saying sorry without deflecting? In the age of the internet? We’re astounded.

Speaking to Metro.co.uk about their experience on the show so far, Jeremy said: ‘The singing has been challenging but we have been enjoying it. I think people might be pleasantly surprised.’

And it seems his duetting buddy is in agreement, as he added: ‘I can speak for both of us when I say bring it on.’
